results.headline: A Man, a Book, a Number: What Does It All Mean?
results.summary_short: “The Number 23” is an accidental comedy starring a deadly serious Jim Carrey.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Number 23

results.headline: Brother and Sister, With Similar Taste in Girls
results.summary_short: “Gray Matters” pretends to be high-end French Champagne, but is really a midpriced domestic vintage.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Gray Matters

results.headline: The Imperfect Soul Who Helped Bring an End to the Slave Trade
results.summary_short: “Amazing Grace,” a prettified take on the life and times of the 18th-century reformer William Wilberforce, carries a strong whiff of piety.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Amazing Grace

results.headline: A Cubist Family Portrait
results.summary_short: A bit of patience is required to get through “The Taste of Tea,” but patience is often rewarded, and it certainly is by this droll and oddly touching film.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Taste of Tea

results.headline: Multiple Choice Love Quiz
results.summary_short: “Starter for Ten” tackles a lofty subject — the allure of knowledge — with down-to-earth charm.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Starter For 10

results.headline: Just Another Desperate Day in the Life of a Drug Casualty
results.summary_short: Watching wasted people stumble from one fix to the next is rarely riveting cinema, and “Cocaine Angel” does little to disprove that rule.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Cocaine Angel

results.headline: The Devil Made Me Do It
results.summary_short: Is the world ready for a flaming Nicolas Cage?

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Ghost Rider

results.headline: Transcending Pain, a Friendship Fed on Imagination
results.summary_short: “Bridge to Terabithia” is a movie whose emotional depth could appeal more to adults than to their offspring.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Bridge to Terabithia

results.headline: Looking to the Future, Living With the Past
results.summary_short: “Grbavica” shows that even as you leave a war behind, you bring it with you.
results.display_title: Grbavica: The Land of My Dreams

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Grbavica: The Land of My Dreams

results.headline: Look Sharp, Ladies, You’re in the Army Now
results.summary_short: If you’ve ever stifled a bubble of rage while going through airport security, you will recognize the tensions in “Close to Home.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Close to Home

results.headline: What Will My Spy Be? Capitalist, Drone, Deviant...
results.summary_short: The thriller “Breach” manages to excite and unnerve despite our knowing the ending.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Breach

results.headline: A Collision of Role Players on the Busy Avenue of Life
results.summary_short: A film about love and art, about passing time and time passing, “Avenue Montaigne” is a humble pleasure.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Avenue Montaigne

results.headline: Dharma, the Elizabethan Way
results.summary_short: Dharma, the time-honored concept of proper conduct, is a recurrent notion in “The Royal Guard,” a somber drama directed by Vidhu Vinod Chopra.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Eklavya: The Royal Guard

results.headline: A Very Busy Father
results.summary_short: The hamfistedness of “Daddy’s Little Girls” ultimately shatters its charms.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Tyler Perry's Daddy's Little Girls

results.headline: Blood on His Hands, Philosophy on His Mind
results.summary_short: "Antibodies" brings together a philosophically minded serial killer, a devoutly religious cop and a cynical filmmaker clearly itching to go Hollywood.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Antibodies

results.headline: World Bank in the Docket, Charged With Africa’s Woes
results.summary_short: “Bamako” is  a work of cool intelligence and profound anger, a long, dense argument that is also a haunting visual poem.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Bamako

results.headline: Melodic Guy, Verbal Gal Meet Cute and Get Lyrical
results.summary_short: “Music and Lyrics” aspires to nothing more than the competent dispensing of mild amusement and easy emotion.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Music and Lyrics

results.headline: Coffee, Tea or an Affair With a Guy?
results.summary_short: Leaving no cliché unturned, “Coffee Date” provides cheesy music, chats about “gaydar” and the obligatory are-you-looking-at-mine? urinal scene.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Coffee Date

results.headline: A Fugue for Good German Men
results.summary_short: “The Lives of Others” is a supremely intelligent, unfailingly honest look at a shadowy period in recent German history.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Lives of Others

results.headline: A Cigar Isn’t Just a Cigar? Ay-Ay-Ay
results.summary_short: The Freudian farce “Unconscious” is paced so breathlessly that it keeps you panting to keep up with each new plot twist.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Unconscious
